boardgame.name: Super Yaniv
boardgame.description:
This is a game for 2-4 players played over several rounds. The aim of the game is to be the player with the smallest sum in hand by the end of the round. Platers are eliminated if their total reaches over 200 points. Once all other players have been eliminated, the remaining player is the winner. It is a derivative/reimplimentation of Yaniv.

Players begin the game with a hand of 5 cards. On their turn, a player first discards one or more cards from the hand (sets of same cards or runs) and then takes a card from the deck or a previous discard. The main difference from the original Yaniv is the inclusion of tactic cards.

boardgame.name: Pericle
boardgame.description:
Pericle is an epic fantasy role playing game that does not require a gamemaster. It takes inspiration from Role playing games (RPGs) like Dungeons & Dragons and Pathfinder, legacy games like Gloomhaven and Pandemic Legacy, and Microquests, like The Fantasy Trip and Dark City Games that tell their stories without a game master by utilizing choose-your-own-adventure mechanics.

Unlike traditional RPGs, Pericle does not require a gamemaster. Instead, players interact with the Pericle Gamemaster, a software program that sits at game-side on the tabletop, guiding the players through the story. The Pericle Gamemaster works much like traditional human GMs, by telling colorful stories, showing images to set the story mood and prompting players for their decisions. Digital videos help tell the story. Active menu choices allow players to explore the world, negotiate with NPCs and make key decisions.
Player choices influence the story outcome. Just like a good, traditional sandbox RPG, players choose their paths through the world - they pick their allies, they decide how and when to mete out justice, where to explore, who to challenge - and in the end, these choices change outcomes. Pericle is a tabletop role playing game, though, not a video game. Even player stats, like health, experience points, treasure, etc, are kept with pencil and paper mechanics - not the software - just like traditional games.

There are 4 stories in the Pericle saga. Each adventure path takes characters from beginner to heroic levels. New characters are used for each adventure - and all 4 stories are woven together in an epic saga. Character development is a key component of the game. Players create and shape their characters, allowing them to feel like the characters are truly their own. When making a character, the player simply chooses to be either a warrior or a wizard. But the talents, skills, masteries and spells the character gains provide a myriad of character choices - and allow a character to behave like a fighter, a rogue, a cleric, a druid and other classes typically found in fantasy games. This simplicity is an example of the game mechanics that make it easy to learn without a human referee, but still feel like a complete RPG.

Pericle's rule system allows freedom of choices, yet has mechanics that allow the world to operate without a human referee. Social interaction is a significant part of roleplaying games, but is difficult to accomplish without a human gamemaster. Pericle therefore encourages players to create background stories for their characters. Characters select a Raison d’Etre (RdE) - which means reason for being - to define a driving characteristic for their actions. Characters may focus their personal goals on charity, economy, scholarly knowledge, law & order or religion. Decisions reward or penalize characters based on alignment with their personal RdE. This encourages players to roleplay their character’s personality, and it comes into play in social interactions with NPCs, planning, and deciding the fate of foes.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Jane Austen's Revenge
boardgame.description:
The cure for a broken heart is... Revenge

Jane Austen’s Revenge is an expansion for Jane Austen’s Matchmaker Chapter Two. Nothing spices up a good romance like a dash of bitterness and betrayal.

As one of Society’s premier matchmakers, your goal remains the same – to gain the most Prestige – but you must also settle scores with your rivals to finish the game holding as few Grudges as possible.

Grudge cards
Each player starts the game with 2 Grudge cards. During play you draw Grudge cards whenever someone does something to vex you – such as declining your proposal. Grudge cards can be played during the game to hurt your rivals. Each Grudge card in your hand subtracts 5 Prestige from your final score. So getting even is always preferable to staying mad.

A Change of Heart card can be played when you propose a match to alter two of your character’s Traits – making one better and the other worse.
Duel

Some grudges can only be settled with a Duel. In polite society this may mean a war of words, a sword fight, pistols at dawn, or even a horse race!

Turmoil cards potentially affect everyone but, if played cleverly, can mitigate the effects on your characters while making your rivals suffer.
Lady Susan

A marriage to the beautiful and capricious Lady Susan is apt to be short and vexatious. A quick divorce later, and she’s back in the game!
Patronage

If things aren’t going your way, you can ask an influential patron to change your luck! If you roll the Trait on the card you may change it to your patron’s preferred Trait instead.

boardgame.name: The Leyfinder
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is a stand alone class from the Cities of Myth project, meant to be used in other settings as well.

The Leyfinder, connected to the lands they travel. The Leyfinder, who can sense the intentions of the very ground under their feat. The Leyfinder who works with magic far older than that known within the world. The Leyfinder is a class which explores infinite possibilities. Built for both combat, exploration and roleplay, a Leyfinder is an adaptable class fit for many situations.

boardgame.name: Vengeance Stalker
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

System Neutral Designs for use with Any Role-Playing Game

5e Compatible Digital Cards Included.

All the contents inside this product are meant to be used as stand-alone material for the "Vengeance Stalker" game tool or inside of your ongoing campaigns by reskinning and adapting them to best fit your games.

boardgame.name: Character Creation for a Doomsday Soldier
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This the first book that will comprise a ruleset to play modern soldiers who find themselves dealing with a world after nuclear bombs have been dropped. This is inspired by several of the games published in the eighties, but this one involves an easier to use ruleset.

The books will come in a a zine format (5.5" x 8.5") which makes it very easy for you to print into booklets for use at your table but is also a nice reading size on your tablet.

This utilizes the Cepheus Engine making it very compatible with books others have written.

boardgame.name: Never Say Never
boardgame.description:
Never Say Never is the hilarious game of horrible hypotheticals. If you’ve ever been that friend who asks your friends if they would do something really wild or crazy for say, a million dollars, then you’re likely the type of person who would get a kick out of this party game.

The rules are pretty simple. During each round of the game, one player challenges the other players with a hypothetical scenario by playing a card from their hand. If the other players would never do it, then whoever played the card gets the point. If somebody (or multiple people) would do it, then they need to explain to the group how on Earth they could justify doing something that ridiculous. Whoever’s answer is deemed the best wins the point in that instance.

The game ends when one player scores 10 points...or after everyone erupts into everlasting laughter and judgement of their friends.

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Personal Combat Rules for a Doomsday Soldier
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:
This the second book that will comprise a ruleset to play modern soldiers who find themselves dealing with a world after nuclear bombs have been dropped. This is inspired by several of the games published in the eighties, but this one involves a easier to use ruleset.

The books will come in a zine format (5.5" x 8.5") which makes it very easy for you to print into booklets for use at your table but is also a nice reading size on your tablet. The plan is to create 3 books that encapsulate the rules set and then offer additional books that focus on settings and GM tools. This utilizes the Cepheus Engine making it very compatible with books others have written.

boardgame.name: The Declassifed Files: Rules for Social Encounters
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Very often role-playing games do not have much in regards to rules or guidance for handling social encounters, and this is especially true for older RPGs. The rules presented here are straightforward and inspired by the B/X reaction tables. This document is filled with many examples to help guide the GM through the process.

boardgame.name: Rite of Passage
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Rite of Passage is the winner of the Sybaroum Adventure Writing Contest 2019: Balads of Blackhawk. This campaign-starter adventure focuses on the wild forests of Davokar and the society that inhabits it - the barbarians.

The characters are young barbarian villagers, completing three sacred trials as they become adults. In contrast to other Symbaroum adventures, the players get to view Davokar from a new, non-Ambrian perspective. This is a thoughful, low-combat scenario that ends near Thistle Hold to easily transition into other published Symbaroum adventures.

GMs are encouraged to review barbarian lore (Symbaroum core book page 27-28) to better reflect their cultures and worldview.

boardgame.name: The Spire in the Hills
boardgame.description:
From the publishers blurb:

It is mid-summer, a time of hot dry days and cool, almost cold nights here in the basin. Someone, perhaps the Saka scout from the previous adventure, has heard that shepherds on the north edge of the basin have seen a tower or spire that was not seen last summer, the last time that they brought their sheep to graze in the cool hills. Others have probably heard about it but there has been no word from any of the guilds in the town or any of the nearby bands of Saka that anyone is doing anything about it. Someone the group knows, very likely the High Priest of the Blue Pool, looked for mentions of a tower in those hills in the library.

They found ample mention, from before the basin dried up. There was a wizard in the hills who was creating new spells and had not accepted any apprentices in many years, so little was known about his activities. He married a wealthy merchant widow and had a tower constructed and was not seen in towns or cities again. The word “wizard,” sometimes “true wizard” meant something other than “a powerful mage” back then and it still does. He was reportedly quite wealthy in his own right. Nothing has been heard of him in centuries and the Initiate thinks people stopped seeing his tower several hundred years ago. They think that the tower must have been hidden by a spell and either the wizard had intended it to reappear or the mana powering it ran out.

This adventure is meant for four to six or so characters that have done some adventuring. Characters who have been through the OSR Blue Pool adventure would be ideal. Advancement differs from campaign to campaign but I think that the characters who went through that adventure would be from third to fifth level, maybe higher, depending in part on how many of the side trips the party made. Some characters might be replaced by new recruits. If you, the GM, has been designing your own adventures, the characters might be a few levels higher and there Is no harm in that.

boardgame.name: Tome of Encounters
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Tome of Encounters has over 40 detailed encounters, ranging in difficulty from Easy to Deadly, in 11 different terrain types. From shipwrecked pirates to chimera ambushes, lost treasures and secret portals, vampire lairs, and basilisk dens, there is always a quick encounter to add a bit of danger at a moments notice! Each encounter is tailored to its environment, average party level, difficulty, and includes level accurate rewards and treasure. Scenes are set up to be quickly inserted into any 5e adventure with little to no preparation. Monster statistics are provided in this bookmarked PDF for easy reference. Some encounters even have additional "hooks" that the GM can use to engage their Players in additional side-quests! Each one to two-page encounter is also presented with a full-color map that details the environment the encounter takes place in and gives a grid that can be used to demonstrate monster and Player positions. The maps will also be included without words or other decorations so the GM can re-use them as they see fit.

boardgame.name: Fliptricks
boardgame.description:
In Fliptricks, you have to be the last standing skater that has performed all of the tricks without falling off of your board or breaking it. All players play at once, perfoming tricks at the same time, and only the best skaters will continue.

Fliptricks is a tiny card-flipping game that uses the edge of the table, a bunch of dexterity and a little luck.


Released in the May 2020 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.

boardgame.name: The Wireless Photosheet
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Horizon scanning real tech for your game

What is Five Minutes into the Future? (5MF)

5MF are a series of short guides scanning the horizon for cutting edge technologies being developed in the real-world right now. Each issue will present one piece of nu-tech and some ways that you can use it in your roleplaying games. 

THIS ISSUE; Volume 1.1 features the Photosheet, a wireless sheet which turns water, sunlight and carbon dioxide into clean fuel.

5MF is largely system neutral, and presents ideas suitable for a variety of modern and near future genres, including:

 modern, 
heist,
espionage,  
technoir,  
near future,  
superhero,  
cyberpunk,  
modern horror,  
hard sci-fi, and 
(post)-apocalyptic. 


Finally, I finish each guide with just a little bit of crunch so you can use the technology (with rules and related character options) in a handful of popular, different systems including;

Fate,
Powered by the Apocalypse, and
D20 modern systems.

boardgame.name: From Nightmares
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A cornucopia of bizarre and upsetting equipment, baubles, and curiosities found in the seedy depths of X-Class stations or the rotting hulls of ghost ships. Guaranteed to make your players say "I hate that" "no" and "f— this."

Compatible with Mothership or your favorite Sci-Fi RPG.

Unearth such wonders as:

A warm thermos filled with fragrant coffee. If consumed, texture chunky and bristling with tiny bones.
Garbage bag with thousands of unidentified medical test strips, all positive.
Deck of cards, doesn't shuffle right.

boardgame.name: Flames of War: Tiger Tank Platoon
boardgame.description:
The Tiger tank has such a reputation amongst Allied tankers, that any tank that held up their advance became a ‘Tiger’.

With armour capable of stopping nearly all Allied anti-tank rounds, and a gun that penetrates Allied tanks with ease, its reputation is well deserved.

—description from the publisher's website
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game

boardgame.name: Empyrean Investigations
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Empyrean Investigations is a book dedicated to bringing mystery to life in your home game of 5th Edition. Inside these pages, players will find ideas and mechanics for building their own detectives, and gamemasters will discover three investigative adventures as well as a guide to running mysteries in their campaigns.

Tales of detectives and investigations hold a hallowed place in our imaginations. Reading through Agatha Christie's "Murder on the Orient Express" or Robert Louis Stevenson's "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" lets us match our wits with those of detectives like Hercule Poirot and Gabriel John Utterson as they explore legendary cases both foul and mysterious. Whether the stories are about petty foibles or supernatural terror, we can't help but turn every page searching for the next clue.

The three stories included in this campaign are an opportunity to bring the feel of a true investigation to your gaming table. Each case hides cryptic clues and devious plots brought to life by a villainous mastermind. Can your players use their powers of deduction to solve each case and bring these dreadful foes to justice?

Then it's time to join Empyrean Investigations!

Five new subclasses for the discerning detective!
Three backgrounds filled with mysterious traits and quirks!
New Rules for investigators, including guidelines for Divination spells!
Three full length adventures featuring codes, puzzles, and more!

boardgame.name: The Hardly Haunted Library
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Duet Adventure for PCs of levels 1-2

With scaling tips through level 8!

All adventurers begin somewhere, and every now and again, the call to adventure is quite bookish in nature!

Shortly before its grand reopening, the Librarium of Linolynn has suffered a serious setback—a ghost has appeared from among the tomes and is attacking innocent library patrons!

The terrifying tales of Timothy Tooth are no longer willing for their author's stories to go unremarked or ignored, and the creatures who dwell within have taken matters into their own, monstrous claws.

Will you brave the literary horror and return the books to their proper place before it's too late?

What's included with the adventure PDF:
This one-shot adventure includes

a librarian NPC
and a special storybook that can help GMs bridge between locations and adventures.
You'll also find a hand-drawn librarium map (both GM's reference in the adventure and a full page for printing)
and a few fun handouts to increase the ambiance for your player.

boardgame.name: Ghost at Home
boardgame.description:
Ghost at Home is a competitive card game where players try to escape from a haunted house. The first player to achieve that will be the winner.

Every player should play cards in order to build the way to the roof of his/her house, but be careful!! there are some ghosts that will try to prevent you from escaping. This game is for all kind of players.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: Watermelon Party
boardgame.description:
pave the way
Watermelon Party is an action puzzle game for 2-4 players where players compete against each other.

Players are given tiles of different shapes and need to lay a path for their hero to walk across the map and collect all the watermelons.

If someone makes a mistake or hits a dead end, they can use bombs to destroy the tiles and rebuild the path. The player who collects all the watermelons first is the winner. The others are ranked by their speed and number of watermelons remaining.

The game is family friendly: Each player can set their own difficulty. Kids and less experienced players get an even playing field versus puzzle geniuses.

The game supports horizontal Joy-Con layout, so two players can play with one pair.

(Nintendo.com description)

boardgame.name: Backbone
boardgame.description:
Backbone is a roleplaying noir detective adventure. Step into the shoes of Howard Lotor, a raccoon private eye. Interrogate witnesses through branching dialogues inspired by classic CRPGs, sneak through diverse districts of a now walled-off dystopian Vancouver, sniff out clues, and choose which leads to follow.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: The Horn & the Scroll
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Are You Prepared For Your Next Session?

Short On Time Or Looking For Extra Content?

An Instant Adventure For Fantasy Roleplaying Games.

The Horn and the Scroll is an adventure designed for a standard group of 3nd to 5th level players. It entails discovering why the local priest of the village of Corden has stolen from the very shrine he maintained and fled with his disciples. It features a hidden temple and some brief exploration thorugh the nearby hills to locate a Unicorns Horn.

Designed for a group of 4-5 players with low to mid-level characters. Use as a standalone adventure, connect to an existing campaign, or as a random encounter in a pinch!

boardgame.name: Otete Artist
boardgame.description:
This game is a party game with a nonfree message transmission system.
The player on your turn uses his or her hand to represent the answer to one of several art cards.
The other players have to guess which card is the one represented by the hand.
The player who guesses, and the player whose turn it is, gets a point!
However, if they all get hit, the turn player gets zero points!

boardgame.name: Lapsus
boardgame.description:
Lapsus is a cooperative word card game. In every round, every player, except the interpreter, receives a secret theme card and 8 syllable cards. Then, they must use their syllable cards to form a word related with the secret theme card they have. After one minute,  all theme cards used by players are shuffled, now it's time for the interpreter to draw one by one the theme cards and assign them to the players based on the concepts they formed, one card to one single player.  Once the interpreter has finished,  players should check how many cards the interpreter has assigned to the right player and score based on this. For next round,  the player situated on the right of the interpreter in the next interpreter.
There is also a competitive variant of the game.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: The Millennium War
boardgame.description:
Once in a Millennium, when all the elements of the Universe are aligned, the Millennium gate emerges and releases powerful cosmic energies in the form of mythical beasts, sacred weapons and spells. This is an opportunity to harness the cosmic energy and win the prolonged war between 2 powerful forces: The Virtues and The Sinners.From around the world come the most powerful heroes from both spectrums. They travel to the dangerous shadow realm to claim the power and to keep it from falling into the enemy’s hands. Whoever shall claim the millennium gate shall win the war, the Millennium War.

In the Millennium War, there are two game modes: competitive mode and cooperative mode. In competitive mode, players go head to head while building their strategy by selecting teams of legendary heroes, buying items, preparing passive spells to counterattack, and most importantly planning their actions by managing mana resources and movement across the Millennium Arena.
There are 3 ways to win in competitive mode: eliminate all your opponents' teams of heroes, destroy all your opponents' ancient structures or claim the Millennium Gate by hunting powerful mythical beasts.
Millennium War's competitive mode is inspired by the popular MOBA games but adjusted to be one of a kind as a board game. You don’t win by speed and accuracy, or control of your keyboard, but by how you think and plan your strategy with a combination of choices. Similar to Chess but way more fun. Whether crushing your enemies with extreme power, trapping them with self destruct explosives and sacrificing one of your hero's for a few of theirs, brain controlling enemy hero's or even switching positions, there are endless ways to gain a strategic advantage. Build combos with 35 special Millennium Hero's and their endless combinations of weapons and spells.
In contrast to the swift pace of Competitive mode is the journey to the Millennium world in Cooperative mode, where players must work together to defeat Millennium Bosses. Each Boss presents a unique way of attack and has its own topography that’ll require the entire team to solve the puzzle to defeat the powerful Boss.
The game offers countless excitement, it’s fun and full of surprises, easy to play and tracks game play because of uniquely designed and patented smart dials, dealer shoes, hero cards and icons. Offering a supporting website featuring hero skills diagrams for easy learning, along with in depth character design inspired by world cultures and game mechanics. The game miniatures are lovingly made with highly detailed craftsmanship by talented artists from around the world. They also magnetically attach to the smart dial.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: Combópolis
Combopolis
Kombopolis
boardgame.description:
With your team's careful guidance, the city and the countryside are expanding and converging. With everything growing at a breakneck pace, you are now tasked with managing the entire region!

A 6-card combo pack that allows you to combine Agropolis and Sprawlopolis.

Unlike the original rules for both standalone games, this variant eliminates the use of card-passing. Rather, players shuffle each game deck individually, flipping a single card from each to reveal 2 scoring conditions. Then, a 3rd card is drawn at random from the 6-card combo pack to reveal the 3rd and final scoring condition. A separate card from this pack is used as the starting tile, displaying 2 "blocks" from those terrains included in each game respectively.

On a player's turn, they draw 1 card from each game deck and must choose 1 to play and 1 to discard. In this way, both game decks with run out at the same rate. End game occurs after the last 2 cards are drawn and played/discarded.

Players score for the largest 2 block groups from each game, lose points for individual roads, and score/lose points according to the 3 scoring condition cards.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Burger Quiz
boardgame.description:
Play all the tests of the funniest and most inventive game on TV: BURGER QUIZ.


2 Teams: Ketchup and Mayo
4 events: Nuggets, Salt or Pepper, Menus and Addition.


Win 25 Yum and try to win the BURGER OF DEATH !!!
So, are you ready for the GAME where wins, pop culture, bad faith, imitations, music and valves coexist in the most joyous of chaos?

The Burger Quiz game box can be played with 2 up to as many players as you want!

Jouez à toutes les épreuves du jeu le plus marrant et inventif de la TV : BURGER QUIZ.
Pour jouer, il vous faut :

Des gens (Vous, Famille, Amis ou d'autres Gens que vous ne connaissez pas ça marche aussi).
Cette Boite de Jeu.


ET C'EST TOUT !

2 Equipes : Ketchup et Mayo
4 épreuves : les Nuggets, le Sel ou Poivre, les Menus et l’Addition, c’est encore mieux que le jeu TV parce que là, c’est VOUS qui jouez – même à “Chewbacca Songs“ !
Gagnez 25 Miam et tentez de remporter le BURGER DE LA MORT !!! (En majuscules ça fait plus peur)
Alors, prêtes et prêts pour le JEU où la gagne, la pop culture, la mauvaise foi, les imitations, la musique et les vannes cohabitent dans le plus joyeux des chaos ?

La boîte de jeu Burger Quiz se joue de 2 à autant de joueurs que vous voulez ! Mais au-dessus de 15, pensez à aérer la pièce.

À partir de 10 ans. Mais si vous avez plus, ça marche très bien aussi !
Peut se jouer à n’importe quelle heure du jour et de la nuit.
Piles non fournies, puisqu’on n’en a pas besoin, c’est ça qu’est bien.
A l’intérieur, plein de trucs que vous savez pas (et d’autres que vous savez, c’est ça qu’est bien) !

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: Dreidel Revolution
boardgame.description:
Dreidel Revolution contains eight brand new games that remain authentic to the traditional Hanukkah game of dreidel, but add new elements to make the dreidel-playing experience better.

The game contains regular dreidels, plus original components like tokens, a Shamash button, and Eight Crazy Dice (d8 with dreidel symbols on them). These components broaden gameplay to allow for choice, strategy, and skill instead of the pure game of chance that is traditional dreidel. The eight games are:

"Gelt or Gift" gives players two competing ways to win and a choice to make after each spin.

"All Together Now" introduces simultaneous spinning so that every player participates in every turn.

"Follow the Leader" is a fairer form of traditional dreidel that gives everyone a chance to beat the best spin/roll combo.

"Beat the Dreidel" is a fast-paced game that requires skill, speed, and luck.

"Spin & Save" raises the stakes in each round, forcing players to choose whether to spend or bank their winnings.

"Hanukkah Chutzpah" tests your ability to tell a lie with a straight face. Can you fool the other players or will you get called out for your chutzpah?

"Superpowered Dreidels" gives each dreidel symbol a superpower that can be used to attack or defend a dreidel spin.

"Maccabee Stacking Bee" takes dreidels to the next level, using them for spinning and as building blocks in ever-growing stacking challenges.

boardgame.name: The 7th Citadel: Aux Frontières du Péril
The 7th Citadel: On the Edge of Peril
boardgame.description:
The Collapsing Lands are aptly named. Every step you take could see the ground open up like a gaping maw, eager to swallow you whole. But what if there were a hidden world below, filled with secrets and treasures just waiting to be discovered?

“On the Edge of Peril” is a Kickstarter exclusive expansion offered in the Collector's Edition pledge.

It expands your adventures with new Exploration cards that will hinder your progress until you fight off the danger.

During your adventure, you may be instructed (no spoilers ?) to slip the “Peril” divider behind the 110 card. Whenever you take a Terrain card stored after that divider (card nr. 111 and up), you must replace 1 Exploration card attached to that terrain with one showing the “Peril” (skull) icon.

Luckily, you possess a Groundquaker, a powerful artifact stolen from the Necrodruids, which will help you push the divider further back and with it the edge of peril!

boardgame.name: Enchiridion of the Computarchs
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The cabalistic and powerful Computarchs built the WorldNet, governed its growth, established its laws and conventions, and seemingly retired from their world altering creation. They left their tools and programs scattered throughout the vast network. Some have been found by seekers such as yourself and have been passed down from generation to generation. Collectively these pieces of software are known as Enchiridion of the Computarchs.

Enchiridion of the Computarchs seeks to give a judge the leg up on developing and using casting mechanics and concepts in high-tech settings. This book encompasses a range of material concerning computers and programs that a “techno-caster” (like the MCC shaman class, or those classes found in Cyber Sprawl Classics, Crawljammer, Umerica, Terror of the Stratosfiend, and Star Crawl Classics) can utilize. You will not only find a collection of spells (aka. programs) in this book but also a new d24 spellburn table, new mechanics for spell failure, and a brief corruption table all couched in a high-technobabble style for your  post-apocalyptic, far-future, and dystopian-future campaigns.
boardgame.rpg: Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game
Mutant Crawl Classics Role Playing Game

boardgame.name: 100 Familiars to Encounter
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Many spellusers of one stripe or another have familiars, creatures that provide aid and unusual abilities. These creatures are often normal animals, although they may have some extra abilities. This supplement has a collection of 100 different things that could be used as familiars, or perhaps pets, that are definitely not normal.

The familiars in this supplement are often not creatures, or alive, and come in a wide range of types. They may provide extra abilities to the individual who owns them, as well as any that might normally be gained from a familiar. Some of the familiars are rather odd in nature, and may not be easily identifiable as to what they are.

This PDF supports Adobe layers and the page backgrounds and images can be disabled to make printing easier.

Here are some sample results:

Mass of fanged mouths and talons in a lump of flesh a foot in diameter. Despite the creature's appearance, it has a cheerful and friendly demeanour.

Metal sphere, 6" in diameter, that hovers in the air. The metal is polished and shiny, but unidentifiable, and the sphere can speak normally and see, despite lacking any apparent sensory or communication orifices.

Meteorite several inches across that always feels cold. It has the ability to communicate telepathically with its owner and is a fragment of a much larger thing, one that knows a lot about dark magic.

Miniature dragon made from stone. The dragon is a real, pygmy dragon that has been petrified. It can communicate telepathically.

Miniature raptor, on three inches tall, that likes snuggling under its owner's clothing to keep warm. Despite its small size, the raptor can still give a nasty bite.

One page is the front cover, one page is the front matter and one page is ads.

boardgame.name: 100 Sights to See in a Steampunk City
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Steampunk settings are filled with astonishing discoveries and marvels of modern science. Characters should be able to hear the hiss of steam, and to smell the scent of warming steel just beneath the city's skin. For those who are looking for unusual sights to really bring home the kind of world the characters are wandering through, from automated street cafes, to bizarre public expos, to dirigible-hosted hangouts for fly boys and sky sailors, then this supplement is just what you've been looking for.

This PDF supports Adobe layers and the page backgrounds and images can be disabled to make printing easier.

Here are some sample results:

Huntington-Locke weapons are seeing a resurgence in popularity throughout the city, both in use by individuals as well as by soldiers of fortune looking for work. These compressed air weapons are just as lethal as more conventional firearms, but rather than an explosion in the barrel they run off of a compressed gas cylinder contained in the weapon's stock. More shots between reloads, and their significantly smaller cost to reload and operate over longer periods of time, makes them ideal for those engaged in a rough trade.

Newspapers blaze with headlines about the sixth murder in a grisly series of crimes that have been taking place in the dock ward. All the victims have had their heads taken off in a single, clean stroke as if the killings had been done with an executioner's sword. The heads are always found hanging from the old gate the next morning, though despite stake outs and watchers the killer has never once been seen. Bloody Jack Takes Another! screams the ink, demanding attention and fear from all those who see the news.

A new exhibit known as the Death Garden has finally opened to the public. Those who wander the grounds of the exhibit can view corpses as they decay under different circumstances, the bodies breaking down and returning to the earth. Though it's been met with a great deal of controversy, called morbid by some and profane by others, the Garden has also become a source of inspiration for poets, painters, musicians and other artists. Those who choose to walk through the Garden on any given day will hear compositions being created, and find perhaps a dozen men and women with easels attempting to capture what they see. Some for art, and others for the furthering of medical science.

Reading benches have recently been installed in the lounges for the train stations and sky ports all around the city. These deep, leather chairs are surrounded by shelves filled with books, and people can freely pick and choose the ones they wish to read. Volumes can even be taken on transports once a passenger boards their car, as long as they're left in benches at their destinations. This ensures that the libraries are constantly shifting, allowing passengers to choose new books for every trip.

Spiders have become particularly popular as pets recently, and the larger the arachnid the more prestige it seems to bring to the one who keeps it. These spiders are often seen riding on their owners' shoulders, or in a "web pocket" on the hip made from netting and wire. One reason that size has become a defining factor is that the larger a spider is, the less venomous it tends to be, and the softer its hairs will be on its owner's skin. Though there are some who prefer small, dangerous spiders for reasons of their own.

One page is the front cover and one page is the front matter.

boardgame.name: Laboratory of the Terramancer
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

In Laboratory of the Terramancer the characters explore the underground complex beneath the former tower of the wizard known as the Terramancer. The complex is constantly changing, as the elementals the Terramancer left behind constantly alter rooms and add or repair traps, making it a dangerous place to explore.

This is aimed at d100 systems but is generic enough in nature to be adapted to others.

This PDF supports Adobe layers and the page backgrounds and images can be disabled to make printing easier.

One page is the front cover, one page is the front matter and one page is ads.

boardgame.name: Rebellion
boardgame.description:
Rebellion is a social deduction party game set in the late Soviet era. It pits those looking to overthrow the government against those seeking to infiltrate and sabotage the resistance.

For setup, players are given unique roles such as Doctor or Hacker (each with a special ability) and then split into two secret teams: Rebels and Spies.

Each player's turn has three steps: Draw, Check, and Recruit. First, a player draws an event card and follows the instructions on it. These cards may do things such as kill other players, change loyalties, or provide valuable information. Then players check to see if enough players are recruited. If there aren't, players end their turn by recruiting another player, who goes next.

When there are enough recruited players, The Rebellion starts: loyalties are revealed and counted. Whichever team got more players recruited wins.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: 100 Notes and Letters to Find in Pugmire
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Characters will often encounter pieces of paper when searching places, or even corpses. Often, these may be important, but important writings shouldn't be the only ones they find. There will be other jottings that people will have written or received. Here are 100 simple notes and letters, threats, orders and warnings, signs of wrongdoing, proof of conspiracies or the ravings of madmen that can be used to disguise what's truly important and to make a setting come to life. Some are quite short and others are longer. These notes are tied to the Urth setting, and could be found in or about a particular location.

Although none are intended to have any meaning beyond being a distraction that appears important, the Guide can, of course, decide whether any of these do have any meaning. These could be used as adventure hooks, or as ways of getting characters to visit certain locations.

This PDF supports Adobe layers and the page backgrounds and images can be disabled to make printing easier.

Kibu the Red is coming!

Krakor, Tell that Mutt Town rat their debts need paying today. Make it absolutely clear that refusal is not an option and bad things will accompany any attempt to weasel out. Take a few leg breakers with you to reinforce the message. I expect a successful payment. Q.

Lot of strangers coming through the north gate recently. I mentioned it to my sergeant, but he didn't seem that bothered. I still find it curious. Maybe I'll follow one of them when I get off my shift.

Make sure this room is spotless. Murra is holding an important meeting here tomorrow. Jake.

Meet me at Granny Sue's at nightfall. Much to discuss. Boris.

Two pages are the front and rear covers, two pahes the Open Game License and one page is legal and ads.

boardgame.name: 100 Books to Find on an Ifrian Bookshelf
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Books can be a source of useful and important knowledge, but libraries are not filled with books that can be described as such. Shelves will also hold books that are less useful; religious tracts, legends, histories, biographies, memoirs, scientific works and fiction. This supplement adds 100 different books that a GameMaster can use to flesh out a bookshelf. All the titles, apart from proper names, are given in English, even though the authors hail from the different countries of Ifri, for ease of use. Whether or not an individual book has anything useful in-game is up to the GM; books can be founts of misinformation as well as knowledge.

This PDF supports Adobe layers and the page backgrounds and images can be disabled to make printing easier.

Khemet in Dance by Tefnakht (How the stories of Khemet are passed down through the generations through ceremonial dances)

Kingdoms of Mbey by Nafissatou (An overview of the different kingdoms that make up Mbey, now dated as it was written before the current troubles)

Land of Many Tongues by Zina Idili (An attempt to catalogue and study all the different languages of Aksum and how they are related to each other)

Legends of the Black Ship by Hamelmal Biruh (Tales from those who have seen the Black Ship, a xebec made of bone, sinew and flesh that has been seen on the four Cardinal Rivers and at sea)

Lovers of War by Bakary (On the Igodomigodoese and their apparent love of conflict)

One page is the front cover, one page is the front matter and one page is ads.

boardgame.name: 5-Min-Superhero
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

5-Min-Superhero is a short, solo TTRPG. You need a six-sided dice and some way of making a journal. A timer is also helpful.

Roll the dice to see who you are and what you are doing and write down what happens. When the time is up, stop writing. This game's theme is Superhero.

boardgame.name: Fallen Corpse
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A woman's body is found lying on the asphalt floor of a busy avenue. Apparently the young woman fell from the seventh floor, from her apartment’s balcony. The body was found at about 2:00 AM by the building's doorman, who called the police immediately upon hearing the sound of her fall.
The young woman was identified as Bette Davis, 30, who lived alone in an expensive apartment and was last seen arriving accompanied by a couple in the previous night around 8:30 PM.

CSI Stories is a collection of short stories for storytelling and Role-Playing Games (RPG) made specifically for the investigative/crime genre of scenarios. To play this story you’ll need one player to be the Storyteller, who will give you information about the story, clues and etc, and 2 to 5 players to play the roles of the Investigators, all of which are CSIs with different expertises.

boardgame.name: The Front: Assault in the Trenches
boardgame.description:
The war game THE FRONT: Assault in the Trenches Solo or two-player game, Powered by combat tables, simulates a trench skirmish at a micro-tactile level.

This game can be found at https://www.wargamevault.com/product/329440/THE-FRONT-Assaul...

Juego solitario o para dos jugadores, Con motor de tablas de combate, simula una escaramusa de trincheras a nivel microtactico.

boardgame.name: Bagels
boardgame.description:
A common defense strategy in Checkers is to keep a piece on the edge of the board so it can not be jumped. This game is played on an edgeless board - a torus. That means all pieces are equally exposed to capture. The top and the bottom of the game board are considered to be connected, as well as the two sides with each other, forming a donut - or bagel - shaped playing field.

A secondary effect of playing on a torus is there is no need for Kings. A piece leaving one edge of the board will simply be re-entered at the appropriate space on the other edge.

Object: Capture all your opponent's Bagels by jumping over them, or stalemate the opponent so he has no moves.

The two sides are known as Plain and Pumpernickel.

Bagels move one square diagonally forward, but may capture in any of the five non-retreating directions - vertically, diagonally forward, or sideways. Jumping over a piece captures it. Capturing is mandatory, and you must keep jumping and capturing as long as it is possible, taking the maximum number of pieces.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Raven Blade
Retro Studios RPG
Rune Blade
boardgame.description: The game would have the player take the role of an unnamed protagonist who would wield the Raven Blade in his adventure to rid the world of evil. The antagonist was named Beastlord. Other than this, not much is known on the plot of the game.

boardgame.name: Animal Wars
boardgame.description:
It was planned to be released some time after Lair, which launched in August, 2007. According to one former employee, work commenced on the title in 2004, “roughly around the time” pre-production on Lair began. It came about as a result of the multi-game contract Factor 5 signed with Sony to produce a number of games exclusive to their platforms. Until the deal expired, the company was set to have every project of theirs fully funded by the publisher, pending their approval. Every title worked on during this partnership was slated for release on PS3 only and Animal Wars was one of them.

Its team was comprised of no more than 4 workers total: 2 designers, 1 dedicated artist and a single programmer. The game was so low down Factor 5’s list of priorities, that every developer assigned to it was at some point repositioned to work on Lair and/or other proposed titles. Animal Wars was set in “an alternate WWI universe with anthropomorphic animal characters”, one developer recalled. The assassination of “the Archduke Birdinand” (a parody of historical figure, Archduke Franz Ferdinand) in the game’s opening served as the catalyst for the great war its campaign would have centered on. The event would have ignited a global conflict between various nations of animals (e.g. felines, bears, foxes, etc.).

The enemy faction consisted of a coalition between ‘Boarmandy’ (boars), The Black Paw (a rogue cat organisation responsible for Birdinand’s murder), bear soldiers, and the main villains, an army of wolves lead by the evil ‘Isegrimm’. An explosive introductory level was set to portray a savage air raid on a city inspired by London, as perpetrated by boars in ‘Big Bertha’ attack blimps. Players would have then found themselves following the exploits of a canine in an aviator jacket, the planned protagonist; although, other playable characters were being explored, too.

boardgame.name: Oric Flight
boardgame.description:
User Summary

In Oric Flight the player can try out the 787 aircraft. The game has a bird's eye view. Made by Geoff M Phillips.

boardgame.name: Neverland: The Impossible Island
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Neverland is a world that exists impossibly amongst the stars. When approaching this floating world, it will appear as a chunk of earth as if someone had sliced into it like a pie. There is no visible sun, or moon within its orbit, but once there, day and night still come.

boardgame.name: Neverland: The Imagination Game
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Welcome to Neverland: The Imagination Game, the game for both children and adults set in the world of J.M. Barrie’s Peter Pan. Neverland is designed to allow a parent, teacher or other adult to introduce children into one of the most famous and well loved, fantastic fictional worlds where they can experience the magic of the fabled island of Neverland to the fullest.

boardgame.name: The Most Wonderful, Magical, Funniest, Spectacular, Eccentric, Chaotic, Murderous... Heckna
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The sounds of revelry drift through the dark, cold forest, drawing wayward travelers to a place where the senses are delightfully and bewilderingly overwhelmed. Peering out from the top of the conifers is the blood-red spire of the Revelia, where wonder and fun awaits!

But underneath the sparkling lights and gleaming facade is a sinister underbelly of chaos, corruption, and calamity. The magical Revelia is the work of Heckna, a creative mastermind masquerading as a jovial ringleader. Some, however, are aware of Heckna’s ruse, including a hunter who will stop at nothing to dispatch Heckna — and destroy the Big Top — once and for all.

Travelers may think that they discover the Revelia by accident or stroke of luck, not knowing that they have in fact been summoned by Heckna, whom revelers call “The Ringleader.” The Ringleader enjoys a challenge, and lures the best and brightest to his circus. Many have tried to escape and failed in the attempt. But all hope is not lost: with the right alliances and a bit of cleverness, even Heckna can be outtricked, and there is a way out through the forest…

Will characters see through the glitzy and glamourous charade or fall prey to Heckna’s everlasting torment and become trapped in the Revelia forever?

boardgame.name: Empowered Barbarians Shrine
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The snowy forested woodlands give way to a large ravine where frigid waters meet after rush down the rocky cliff side. Thick vines have grown around rocks creating a small bridge to the other side where a path leads towards a small altar. The altar is surrounded by two other small streams and sits at the highest point on the rock it was built on.

Below the altar are five trinkets made from skulls and carved wood corresponding to the four large obelisks that surround the area as well as the shrine itself where magical energy swirl and pulsates with power. Within this opening in the wilds you can marvel at the stars which shine above.

boardgame.name: Svenska konungar och drottningar
boardgame.description:
This game has a basic Go Fish gameplay but with changes to set make-up, collection and scoring. Each card features a king, queen or queen consort of Sweden, most of them grouped into royal houses. Sets are collected as singles where applicable, complete houses, or "families" (partial houses). If a family has been collected, remaining cards from that house can be freely collected as "bonus cards" for lesser points, but whichever other conditions apply, a king must be collected along with their consort or consorts. Play continues as in regular Go Fish until the draw deck is empty and all cards have been claimed, at which time points are counted up from singles, houses, families and bonus cards to find the winner.

—user summary

Each piece of property is identified by the surname of the prior owner (examples: Miller Residence, Smith Place, Jones Property, etc.). In addition there are details regarding what kind of architectural style the home is, how many bedrooms and bathrooms, a random detail about the home or the property (including some potential encounters), and some ready to drop in loot items that the exploring survivors will find at this location. Feel free to add as many other bits of loot and information that you wish!

Included in each entry is the following: First name and surname, gender (most are males but there are a few lasses), a general descriptive element about the character, weapon(s) carried and used, coins on their person, and a special treasure/carried item.

Random roll the percentile dice to use just one or a few, or fill up that cursed old galleon with the whole wretched lot of these scoundrels!

This list is suitable for historical era and fantasy settings alike.

This product is perfect if you are trying to establish a safehouse group and you need an assortment of talents and personalities. Each entry contains the slayer’s name, their gender, their age, their major talent, a general descriptive, carried weapon(s), and some form of carried loot.
